cmCourseInfo.description: Practical tools for writing in university and beyond. Students will gain experience in generating ideas, clarifying insights, structuring arguments, composing paragraphs and sentences, critiquing and revising their writing, and communicating effectively to diverse audiences. This course may not count toward any English program.
cmCourseInfo.title: Effective Writing

cmCourseInfo.description: Practical tools for writing in university and beyond. Students will gain experience in generating ideas, clarifying insights, structuring arguments, composing paragraphs and sentences, critiquing and revising their writing, and communicating effectively to diverse audiences. This course may not count toward any English program.
cmCourseInfo.title: Effective Writing

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of how recent literature in English responds to our world. Includes poetry, prose, and drama by major writers of the twentieth century and emerging writers of the current century.
cmCourseInfo.title: Literature for our Time

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to major authors, ideas, and texts that shaped and continue to inform the ever-evolving traditions of literature in English. Includes works and authors from antiquity to the nineteenth century such as the Bible, the Qur'an, Plato, Homer, Sappho, Virgil, Dante, Christine de Pizan, Shakespeare, Cervantes, Montaigne, Austen, Dostoevski.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Literary Tradition

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to poetry through a close reading of texts, focusing on its traditional forms, themes, techniques, and uses of language; its historical and geographical range; and its twentieth-century diversity.
cmCourseInfo.title: Reading Poetry

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to influential texts that have shaped the British literary heritage, covering approximately twelve writers of poetry, drama, and prose, from Chaucer to Keats, with attention to such questions as the development of the theatre, the growth of the novel form, and the emergence of women writers.
cmCourseInfo.title: British Literature: Medieval to Romantic

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Students enrolled in L0101 are to enroll in a tutorial section at R1 or R2.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the novel through a reading of ten to twelve texts, representing a range of periods, techniques, regions, and themes.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Novel

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Students enrolled in L0101 are to enroll in a tutorial section at W11 or W12.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores shorter works of nineteenth- and twentieth-century writers. Special attention is paid to formal and rhetorical concepts for the study of fiction as well as to issues such as narrative voice, allegory, irony, and the representation of temporality.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Short Story

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the Canadian short story, this course emphasizes its rich variety of settings, subjects, and styles.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Canadian Short Story

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the Canadian short story, this course emphasizes its rich variety of settings, subjects, and styles.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Canadian Short Story

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: January 17, 2017. Please note T0207 will take place in UC69 on March 15th only.

cmCourseInfo.description: A representative survey of Shakespeare's work, covering the different periods of his career and the different genres in which he worked. Readings may include such plays as The Taming of the Shrew, Richard III, Henry IV, Twelfth Night, Hamlet, Macbeth, and The Tempest. Non-dramatic poetry may also be included.
cmCourseInfo.title: Shakespeare

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
ENG220Y1: Students enrolled in L0101 are to enroll in a tutorial section at W9 or W10.

cmCourseInfo.description: A critical and historical study of poetry and fiction written for or appropriated by children, this course may also include drama or non-fiction and will cover works by at least twelve authors such as Bunyan, Stevenson, Carroll, Twain, Alcott, Nesbit, Montgomery, Milne, Norton, Fitzhugh.
cmCourseInfo.title: Children's Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: A critical and historical study of poetry and fiction written for or appropriated by children, this course may also include drama or non-fiction and will cover works by at least twelve authors such as Bunyan, Stevenson, Carroll, Twain, Alcott, Nesbit, Montgomery, Milne, Norton, Fitzhugh.
cmCourseInfo.title: Children's Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to book-length sequential art, this course includes fictional and nonfictional comics by artists such as Will Eisner, Art Spiegelman, Frank Miller, Alan Moore, Chris Ware, Daniel Clowes, Julie Doucet, Marjane Satrapi, Chester Brown, Seth.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Graphic Novel

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to book-length sequential art, this course includes fictional and nonfictional comics by artists such as Will Eisner, Art Spiegelman, Frank Miller, Alan Moore, Chris Ware, Daniel Clowes, Julie Doucet, Marjane Satrapi, Chester Brown, Seth.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Graphic Novel

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores speculative fiction that invents or extrapolates an inner or outer cosmology from the physical, life, social, and human sciences. Typical subjects include AI, alternative histories, cyberpunk, evolution, future and dying worlds, genetics, space/time travel, strange species, theories of everything, utopias, and dystopias.
cmCourseInfo.title: Science Fiction

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores speculative fiction of the fantastic, the magical, the supernatural, and the horrific. Subgenres may include alternative histories, animal fantasy, epic fantasy, the Gothic, fairy tales, magic realism, sword and sorcery, and vampire fiction.
cmCourseInfo.title: Fantasy and Horror

cmCourseInfo.description: Prepares students to read the oldest English literary forms in the original language. Introduces the earliest English poetry in a woman's voice, expressions of desire, religious fervour, and the agonies of war. Texts, written 680 - 1100, range from the epic of Beowulf the dragon-slayer to ribald riddles.
cmCourseInfo.title: Old English Language & Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: An introductory survey of major works in American literature, this course explores works in a variety of genres, including poetry, fiction, essays, and slave narratives.
cmCourseInfo.title: American Literature

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Students enrolled in L0101 are to enroll in a tutorial section at W1 or W2.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introductory survey of major Canadian works in poetry, prose, and drama from early to recent times.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Literature

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Students enrolled in L0101 are to enroll in a tutorial section at R11 or R12.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to Indigenous North American writing in English, with significant attention to Aboriginal literatures in Canada. The writings are placed within the context of Indigenous cultural and political continuity, linguistic and territorial diversity, and living oral traditions. The primary focus is on contemporary Indigenous writing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Indigenous Literatures of North America

cmCourseInfo.description: In this course we study literary and non-literary texts from the nineteenth century to the present day. Colonial texts are analysed alongside postcolonial interpretations of the nineteenth-century archive, giving students a grasp of colonial discourse and contemporary postcolonial analyses.
cmCourseInfo.title: Colonial and Postcolonial Writing

cmCourseInfo.description: Introducing a lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans, and queer tradition in literature and theory, this course explores classical, modern, postmodern, and contemporary literature, criticism, art, film, music, and popular culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Queer Writing

cmCourseInfo.description: A practical introduction to literary theory and its central questions, such as the notion of literature itself, its political underpinnings, the relation between literature and reality, the making of literary canons, and the roles of the author and the reader.
cmCourseInfo.title: Critical Approaches to Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: The foundation of English literature: in their uncensored richness and range, Chaucer's works have delighted wide audiences for over 600 years. Includes The Canterbury Tales, with its variety of narrative genres from the humorous and bawdy to the religious and philosophical, and Troilus and Criseyde, a profound erotic masterpiece.
cmCourseInfo.title: Chaucer

cmCourseInfo.description: Writers of this period grapple with questions of authority and individualism, tradition and innovation, in politics, religion, knowledge, society, and literature itself. Special attention to Dryden, Pope, Swift, Johnson, and at least six other authors.
cmCourseInfo.title: Poetry and Prose, 1660-1800

cmCourseInfo.description: Poetry and critical prose of Blake, W. Wordsworth, Coleridge, Byron, P.B. Shelley, and Keats; may include selections from other writers such as Crabbe, Scott, Landor, Clare, D. Wordsworth, M. Shelley, De Quincey.
cmCourseInfo.title: Romantic Poetry and Prose

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores a selection of writings in early English, excluding those by Chaucer.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medieval Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores a selection of writings in early English, excluding those by Chaucer.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medieval Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: This course studies the emergence of prose fiction as a genre recognized in both a literary and a commercial sense. Authors may include Behn, Defoe, Richardson, Fielding, Sterne, Scott, and Austen.
cmCourseInfo.title: Fiction before 1832

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of selected novels of Jane Austen and of works by such contemporaries as Radcliffe, Godwin, Wollstonecraft, Wordsworth, Edgeworth, Scott, and Shelley, in the context of the complex literary, social, and political relationships of that time.
cmCourseInfo.title: Austen and Her Contemporaries

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of selected novels of Jane Austen and of works by such contemporaries as Radcliffe, Godwin, Wollstonecraft, Wordsworth, Edgeworth, Scott, and Shelley, in the context of the complex literary, social, and political relationships of that time.
cmCourseInfo.title: Austen and Her Contemporaries

cmCourseInfo.description: Exploring the social and political dilemmas of a culture in transition, this course studies such topics as the comic art of Dickens, Trollope, and Thackeray, the Gothicism of the Brontës, the crisis of religious faith in George Eliot, and the powerful moral fables of Hardy. Students will read 10-12 novels.
cmCourseInfo.title: Fiction, 1832-1900

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores forms of realism in Victorian fiction and includes at least six novels by such authors as Dickens, Thackeray, George Eliot, Charlotte Brontë, Gaskell, Collins, Trollope, Hardy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Victorian Realist Novels

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores ten to twelve works by such writers as James, Conrad, Cather, Forster, Joyce, Woolf, Lawrence, Faulkner, Rhys, Hemingway, Achebe, Ellison, Spark, Lessing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Fiction to 1960

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores six or more works by at least four British contemporary writers of fiction.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary British Fiction

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores six or more works by at least four British contemporary writers of fiction.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary British Fiction

cmCourseInfo.description: Texts and performances preceding and underlying the plays of Shakespeare and his contemporaries, including creation-to-doomsday play cycles; plays performed in parishes, inns, great halls, outdoor arenas, and at court; religious and political propaganda plays; political pageants. Attention to social, political, and theatrical contexts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Early Drama

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores English drama to the end of the reign of Queen Elizabeth I, with attention to such playwrights as Lyly, Kyd, Marlowe, Shakespeare.
cmCourseInfo.title: Drama to 1603

cmCourseInfo.description: A concentrated study of one aspect of Shakespeare's work, such as his use of a particular genre, a particular period of his work, a recurring theme, or the application of a particular critical approach.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Shakespeare
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 2.0 ENG FCE including ENG220Y1, and any 4.0 FCE

cmCourseInfo.description: A concentrated study of one aspect of Shakespeare's work, such as his use of a particular genre, a particular period of his work, a recurring theme, or the application of a particular critical approach.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Shakespeare
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 2.0 ENG FCE including ENG220Y1, and any 4.0 FCE

cmCourseInfo.description: At least twelve plays, including works by Dryden, Wycherley, Congreve, and their successors, chosen to demonstrate the modes of drama practised during the period, the relationship between these modes and that between the plays and the theatres for which they were designed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Drama, 1660-1800

courses.name: Modern Drama to World War II

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of plays in English by such dramatists as Wilde, Yeats, Shaw, Synge, Glaspell, Hughes, O'Neill, as well as plays in translation by such dramatists as Ibsen, Chekhov, Strindberg, Pirandello.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Drama to World War II

courses.name: Modern Drama since World War II

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of plays by such dramatists as Beckett, Miller, Williams, Pinter, Soyinka, Churchill, with background readings from other dramatic literatures.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Drama since World War II

cmCourseInfo.description: Writers (such as Darwin, Tennyson, Browning, Wilde, Nightingale, Christina Rossetti, Kipling) respond to crisis and transition: the Industrial Revolution, the Idea of Progress, and the "Woman Question"; conflicting claims of liberty and equality, empire and nation, theology and natural selection; the Romantic inheritance, Art-for-Arts-Sake, Fin de siècle, and "Decadence."
cmCourseInfo.title: Victorian Poetry and Prose

cmCourseInfo.description: Special study of Yeats, Pound, Eliot, Auden, Stevens; selections from other poets.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Poetry to 1960

cmCourseInfo.description: Works by at least six contemporary poets, such as Ammons, Ashbery, Heaney, Hughes, Lowell, Muldoon, Plath.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary Poetry

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of ten to twelve Canadian works of fiction, primarily novels.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Fiction

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of major Canadian poets, modern and contemporary.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Poetry

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of works by Indigenous women writers from North America and beyond, with significant attention to Aboriginal writers in Canada. Texts engage with issues of de/colonization, representation, gender, and sexuality, and span multiple genres, including fiction, life writing, poetry, drama, film, music, and creative non-fiction.
cmCourseInfo.title: Indigenous Women's Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores American writing in a variety of genres from the end of the Revolution to the beginning of the twentieth century.
cmCourseInfo.title: Nineteenth-Century American Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores twentieth-century American writing in a variety of genres.
cmCourseInfo.title: Twentieth-Century American Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores six or more works by at least four contemporary American writers of fiction.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary American Fiction

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores six or more works by at least four contemporary American writers of fiction.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary American Fiction

cmCourseInfo.description: What, if anything, is distinctively "African" in African texts; what might it mean to produce "African" readings of African literature? We address these, as well as other quiestions, through close readings of oral performances and literary and other cultural texts.
cmCourseInfo.title: African Literatures in English (formally ENG278Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Literature and cultures of Asian Canadians and Asian Americans, including fiction, poetry, theory, drama, film, and other media.
cmCourseInfo.title: Asian North American Literature (formally ENG268H1)

courses.name: South Asian Literatures in English (formally ENG269H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Major authors and literary traditions of South Asia, with specific attention to literatures in English from India, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and the diaspora. The focus will be on fiction and poetry with some reference to drama.
cmCourseInfo.title: South Asian Literatures in English (formally ENG269H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on recent theorizations of postcoloniality and transnationality through readings of fictional and non-fictional texts, along with analyses of contemporary films and media representations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Postcolonial and Transnational Discourses

cmCourseInfo.description: Literary theory from classical times to the nineteenth century. Topics include theories of the imagination, genre analysis, aesthetics, the relations between literature and reality and literature and society, and the evaluation and interpretation of literature.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of Literary Theory

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores literary theory from the early twentieth century to the present. Schools or movements studied may include structuralism, formalism, phenomenology, Marxism, post-structuralism, reader-response theory, feminism, queer theory, new historicism, psychoanalysis, postcolonial theory, and cultural and race studies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary Literary Theory

cmCourseInfo.description: Sustained study of one school, movement, or approach in literary theory, history, or criticism. Content varies with instructors.
cmCourseInfo.title: Critical Methods

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to psychoanalysis for students of literature, this course considers major psychoanalytic ideas through close readings of selected texts by Freud. The course also explores critiques and applications of Freud's work and examines a selection of literary texts that engage psychoanalytic theory.
cmCourseInfo.title: Literature and Psychoanalysis

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores English from its prehistory to the present day, emphasizing Old, Middle, and Early Modern English and the theory and terminology needed to understand their lexical, grammatical, and phonological structure; language variation and change; codification and standardization; literary and non-literary usage.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of the English Language

cmCourseInfo.description: Restricted to students who in the opinion of the Department show special aptitude for writing poetry, fiction, or drama. For application procedure, see the descriptions online and submit an application by May 15. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Creative Writing
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 2.0 ENG FCE, any 4.0 FCE and permission of the instructor and the Associate Chair

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
To enrol in this course, visit www.english.utoronto.ca and submit a signed proposal form by May 15th. For more information please contact the Department of English at english.undergraduate@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: A scholarly project chosen by the student and supervised by a member of the staff. The form of the project and the manner of its execution are determined in consultation with the supervisor. All project proposals should be submitted by May 15. Proposal forms are available online and from the Department. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Individual Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 3.0 ENG FCE, any 4.0 FCE and permission of the instructor and the Associate Chair

Proposal forms are available online and from the Department. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 3.0 ENG FCE, including ENG389Y1, any 4.0 FCE and permission of the instructor and the Associate Chair

cmCourseInfo.description: A seminar designed to provide students with the opportunity to practice their skills of research and interpretation at a particularly advanced level. Admission by invitation and permission of the instructor and the Associate Chair. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Research Seminar
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 4.0 ENG FCE, any 9.0 FCE, and permission of the Department.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
To enrol please contact the Department of English at english.undergraduate@utoronto.ca. Eligible students will be emailed and invited to submit a statement by the end of May, and offers will be sent by the end of June.
